Turn a Programming Project Into a Citations Network

vignette_get_doc_network_from_project.Rmd

This Vignette give a basic understanding of the network computed by codexplor::get_doc_network_from_project : a Citations Network of functions within programming project(s).

Example

Given folders path(s) and/or github repo(s), compute a citations network of the functions with 

    net <- get_doc_network_from_project(repos =  c("tidyverse/stringr", "clement-lvd/codexplor"))
    # by default, codexplor deal with R project

Then turn this edgelist into an interactive dataviz‚Äô with networkD3 :

    get_networkd3_from_igraph(net$citations_network)
    # Return an interactive dataviz' from networkD3

By default, get_networkd3_from_igraph will colorize the nodes accordingly to their indegrees. This will reveal the local dependancies of the programming project (i.e.¬†functions used by others files of the project).

.

(codexplor functions network is truncated)

For example, the most-common local dependancy inside the tidyverse/stringr repo is compat-types-check.R, [‚Ä¶] and we see that one of the codexplor file actually rely on a stringrmethod (i.e.¬†codexplor::str_extract_all_to_tidy_df.R rely on stringr/extract.R). The opposite is not true.

Playing with the parameters will reveal others insights, e.g., you should try to color nodes accordingly to their outdegrees, in order to reveal the high-level files of the project.

Network properties

The returned network is a document-to-document citations network.

These networks have basic properties, not covered here (e.g., a citations network is a directed network).

Regarding the network computed by codexplor::get_doc_network_from_project() :

  • Nodes are the programming files, default is a network of .R files.
  • Edges go from the file that calls a function to the file where the function is defined.

Thus, in a typical programming project :

  • Nodes are files, so mostly - or only - functions ;
  • ¬∞‚Üê Indegree of a file is ‚Äúhow many files are calling the function(s) defined in this file‚Äù ;
  • ¬∞‚Üí Outdegree of a file is ‚Äúhow many functions are used by this file‚Äù ;
  • ‚ü≤ Auto-mentioning refear to ‚Äòrecursivity‚Äô (codexplor default is to filter autolinks).

Cascading matching operated by get_doc_network_from_project

Assuming the user have indicated folder(s) and/or github repo(s), codexplor::get_doc_network_from_project() will try to perform a ‚Äòcascading matching‚Äô :

‚è© Read the files and extract a 1st pattern, e.g., default are supposed to extract R functions names as a 1st matches, e.g., we have defined ‚ÄòPier‚Äô, ‚ÄòPol‚Äô and ‚ÄòJak‚Äô - functions - names.

‚è© Search for these patterns in the initial content, in order to constitute a Citations Network with the 2nd matches, e.g., the content from a programming file is citing ‚ÄòPier‚Äô, ‚ÄòPol‚Äô and ‚ÄòJak‚Äô.

üéÅ Return the edgelist that symbolize this network of documents, by default it‚Äôs a network of internal dependencies within the files of a programming project.

codexplor default pattern are aimed to extract functions names from the files of a programming project (links are beginning from the programming file that is calling a function => to the programming file where this function is defined).

Function call that are non-supported during 2nd matches

Some way of writing a program are not fully supported, such as :

Python instantiated methods. The instantiated Python methods are not supported yet by get_doc_network_from_project, i.e.¬†obj.method().

If we take this Python code sample, the 1st match is realized by construct_corpus, but get_doc_network_from_project don‚Äôt perform a 2nd match.

#  Consider the Python code herafter 
class A:
    def method(self):
        return "My custom method"
 # construct_corpus return 'method' as a 1stly matched function name

obj = A()
obj.method() # Return : 'My custom method'

# get_doc_network_from_project don't identify the 2nd match because of the prefix ("obj.")

Filter undesired match

Junk nodes needs to be excluded from the network. Typical ‚Äúfalse positive‚Äù matches are the lines where you use the name of another function in a message, e.g.¬†message("my_func() is deprecated. You should use this_function() instead). get_doc_network_from_project offer several parameters for dealing with your style of writing a program.

Crafting your own corpus with codexplor

Depending on the languages you have to manage, you‚Äôll want to tweak the ‚Äòpattern‚Äô used for match a function definition, since for now codexplor support only the R programming language (other languages are planned). See the vignette of construct_corpus.
